Secondly, the incentive must be for a specified activity listed in the notes which will result in genuine economic development and active business income. The third condition allows for the exclusion of certain activities and tax sparing incentives. These include the banking and the finance sector, and some shipping and aircraft operations. Also included in this condition is a general anti‐avoidance provision.

At the time of the negotiations on the parameters of the credit notes there were a variety of tax rates applicable to foreign investors in Vietnam. These ranged from 25 per cent down to 10 per cent. It was therefore important to establish a benchmark for the underlying rate in order to calculate the amount of tax forgone by Vietnam. It was agreed that this benchmark rate would be 20 per cent.

BREAK.PARA: As is the custom in Australia with tax sparing arrangements, the benefits are provided to Australian residents for a period of 10 years. There is provision for the extension of this period, which began on 1 July 1993, on the grounds of a future agreement. The notes will enter into force when the future exchanging of diplomatic notes advising of the necessary constitutional processes has been fulfilled. A final binding treaty, and the enactment of this legislation, will complete the processes required by Australia for these purposes. This exchange of notes is an important step in the recognition by Australia of the importance of Vietnam to our region.

In the last few years Vietnam has started taking great strides in its economic development. On 28 July 1995 Vietnam became a full member of ASEAN. Only two weeks earlier, the USA announced its normalisation of diplomatic relations between the two countries. These were two significant events in the opening of Vietnam to international trade and growth.

Basic elements of commercial operations are currently in place and rapidly expanding. There are an abundant number of business opportunities emerging but there is currently not enough local capital to develop these possibilities. During the 1990s, Australia has experienced a tenfold increase in bilateral trade with Vietnam and we are currently one of the top 10 foreign investors in Vietnam.

As part of the coalition government's commitment to assisting trade in our region, the minister, Mr Fischer, established the Market Development Task Force in 1996. The role of the task force is to better coordinate government activity within the trade portfolio. The task force is involved in setting realistic and achievable priorities in bilateral market access, trade promotion and trade development. The task force is about achieving outcomes and has recently given close examination to the emerging markets in our region, including an examination of the possibilities arising from increased growth in Vietnam.

The relationship between Australia and Vietnam is one of increasing strength and cooperation. As part of Tuesday's federal budget, the government announced that country program assistance to Vietnam will be maintained. This means a coalition commitment of $66 million in aid to Vietnam over 1997‐98. Projects in Vietnam that will be funded include malaria prevention, providing a reliable supply of clean water, general sanitation projects, and the construction of the My Thuan bridge. The My Thuan bridge will open up the Mekong delta to increased economic development and is one of Vietnam's highest infrastructure priorities.

This bill is an important part of our increasing trade relationship. It is a signal to the Vietnamese that we are taking our maturing trade relationship seriously. As trade between our two countries increases, it is important that the government can come to a fair agreement on tax sparing that matches the changing nature of the trade relationship. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The International Tax Agreements Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1997 sets out to enhance Australian business opportunities in Vietnam by providing a more agreeable tax environment. It serves to formalise Australia's undertaking, given in 1992, to grant tax sparing arrangements for specific Vietnamese tax concessions.

SPEECH.PARA: Double tax agreements are generally supported in principle by Australian tax experts and are acknowledged to be an integral part of our economic internationalisation. However, a submission made to the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties in March of this year on behalf of the Institute of Chartered Accountants, the ICA, reveals a number of concerns with this particular agreement. The ICA is concerned not only with the limited application of the legislation to Australian exporters but also with the lack of consultation with industry in the treaty making process.

The member for Braddon (Mr Miles), in his second reading speech on behalf of the government rightly points out that tax sparing is utilised by the Vietnamese government to encourage international investment in Vietnam. He also suggested that without tax sparing credits:

. . . Vietnamese tax concessions granted to Australian residents could be negated by Australia's foreign tax credit rules which would effectively top up Vietnamese taxes paid to the level of tax that would be payable on an equivalent amount of Australian domestic income.

He paints a very rosy picture of the benefits of tax sparing for Australian investors in Vietnam. Those Australian companies which qualify for the exemption will no longer be forced to pay the difference between Vietnam's tax rate and Australia's. This is both reasonable and sensible.
The Institute of Chartered Accountants makes it clear that whilst tax sparing does not represent a cost to Australian revenue:

Many of the features of the tax sparing agreement are those insisted upon by the Vietnamese government. These include the cap on the tax sparing rate, the exclusion of accounting and auditing services from tax sparing relief, and the defined permitted activities.

The ICA acknowledges at the same time that these conditions are consistent with Vietnamese domestic taxation law. However, it is obvious that only a limited pool of Australian investors in Vietnam will benefit from this agreement. Services—including accounting, consulting, banking, commercial and insurance—will not be able to utilise the tax sparing agreement.

The Treasurer (Mr Costello) has also conceded that aircraft and shipping operations will only benefit in part from this tax relief. Many tax experts believe this to be inappropriate. The Institute of Chartered Accountants maintains that other prospective tax sparing agreements should not be restricted to reflect the domestic law of the country in which the tax sparing income is sourced.
It agrees that some Australian enterprises could be encouraged to export to foreign markets by tax sparing negotiations, but it stipulates that:
Until the source country extends its domestic law to allow a tax concession, no practical issue will arise.
The ICA agreed that it is necessary to maintain the integrity of tax sparing arrangements with Vietnam, but it went on to note:
In material terms, the Vietnamese domestic law will limit tax sparing available to Australian taxpayers, and this would make the conclusion of the double tax agreement expedient in its present form.

To date, our trade with Vietnam has been quite limited. Australia's 1995‐96 trade table showed Vietnam as 32nd among our top 45 trading partners. Total two‐way trade between Australia and Vietnam in that year amounted to around $527 million, which represented a 0.3 per cent share of our total trade figures. Significantly though, our total export dollars were almost half that of our total import expenditure. In fact, our net exports are calculated at minus $131 million for the year 1995‐96.

This figure represents a substantial reversal in the flow of trade from 1989 to 1990, when Australian exports exceeded Vietnamese imports by some $66 million. We certainly have some ground to make up if we are to establish balanced two‐way trade with our Vietnamese partner. Now is the time to do it.

BREAK.PARA: David Lague, a journalist with the Australian Financial Review, observed on 3 March 1997 that:
Vietnam's economic reforms and the possibility of funding from the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank, mean trade could grow rapidly over the rest of the decade.

Mr Lague notes that, as Vietnam overcomes longstanding regional antagonisms and re‐establishes economic relations, both within and outside the Asian domain, investment opportunities in Vietnam will boom.

The formalisation of this double tax agreement and the recent appointment of Australia's first trade commissioner to Hanoi are a recognition of the opportunities evolving in Vietnam. Australia currently ranks as the third biggest foreign investor in Vietnam, trailing only Taiwan and Hong Kong. A number of analysts predict that the United States will soon reassess its trade embargo on Vietnam and that it is essential that Australia consolidates its investment and trade relationships with Hanoi before that occurs.

As indicated earlier, the ICA's submission to the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties expressed concern over the inadequate consultation in the formulation of this double tax agreement. It correctly asserts that the Australian Taxation Office should seek early and extensive deliberations with all relevant professional parties. The ICA submission goes on to read in part:
Future tax related international agreements should be subject to the full consultative progress, as occurs and operates well in some other aspects of taxation law and policy.
The clear inference there is that proper and meaningful consultation with industry did not occur in this case.

This bill formalises an undertaking made five years ago between the Australian and Vietnamese governments. There is no excuse for the circumstances described, or for the former government not to have canvassed industry feedback on the nature of the agreement in that period. Given the coalition's election commitment to reforming the treaty making process, there is no justification whatsoever for this tardy management of legislation.
In his speech on 2 May 1996, the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) promised the Australian community a more consultative and accountable treaty making process. Amongst other things he said:
Every Australian individual and interest group with a concern about treaty issues has the opportunity to make that concern known.

Consultation will be the key word, and the government will not act to ratify a treaty unless it is able to assure itself that the treaty action proposed is supported by national interest considerations.

Clearly, the Institute of Chartered Accountants is not satisfied with either the timing or the extent of consultation on this particular tax agreement. They argue that they have not seen the Minister for Foreign Affairs' `democratic deficit' in our treaty making process applied in this instance.

The ICA submission suggests that organisations with expertise in the field of international tax law should be consulted once the initial round of diplomatic negotiations has been conducted. I am interested to hear the coalition's response to this recommendation, given its pledge to its Australian electors at the last election to be more inclusive than its predecessor.

The parliamentary Joint Standing Committee on Treaties noted that the consultation with industry was unsatisfactory in the lead‐up to making the double tax agreement with Vietnam. The member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss), who sits on the treaties committee, noted that there had seemingly been no discussion with the professional bodies in Australia in regard to this international tax agreement. He observed:

This was a very complex issue, and it was only when the committee drew attention to the fact that there had been this lack of consultation that there was able to be a resolution of some of the issues of concern. The consultation should not be left to the time when the Treaties Committee makes these reviews.
I repeat what he said:
The consultation should not be left to the time when the Treaties Committee makes these reviews.
The chairman of the committee, the member for Groom (Mr Taylor), said:
We were concerned that the consultation between the ATO and professional accounting bodies and the quality of the national interest analysis that accompanied the agreement was less than satisfactory.
According to the chairman, the national interest analysis—the NIA—was not only unnecessarily difficult to understand but it actually omitted important information.

The whole point of introducing NIAs was to facilitate parliamentary scrutiny of treaties. In the words of the Minister for Foreign Affairs, they are designed to `note the reasons why Australia should become a party to a treaty.' The exclusion of important information from any NIA, whether the exclusion is intentional or not, has the potential to render the whole process a farce.

The ICA is not only concerned about the timing of the dialogue between industry and the government, it is equally concerned with the content of this dialogue. It suggests that for Australia's treaty making process to be fully transparent, consultation with industry should cover all aspects of the proposed tax agreement. The ICA's report said:
There is no justification for the consultation to be confined to those areas of a treaty which the ATO or Treasury decide are significant.

If the ATO has reservations due to the confidential nature of the international negotiations, it is submitted that they are unfounded. Members of the profession have expressed their willingness to sign the same secrecy provisions which bind members of the ATO in order to promote consultation.

Neither the ATO nor the Treasury should wield discretionary power in this matter. The Institute of Chartered Accountants is right to assert that all aspects of this and future international tax agreements should be the subject of objective and consistent checks and balances. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) is recorded in Hansard as having said:

I firmly believe that the impact of international laws in the domestic context makes it imperative that we continue to improve (that) transparency and recognise the fundamental right of people to scrutinise the way international law is made.

Amen to that. That was what the minister had to say 12 months ago; yet here we are today, debating only the second international tax agreement since he made that remark, and we have both the Institute of Chartered Accountants and the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties questioning the treaty making process.

The bill does provide incentives for certain Australian businesses to develop the Vietnamese market—to what extent, though, is anyone's guess. The fact that the financial impact statement provided with the proposed legislation can at best only estimate an annual cost to revenue of somewhere between $10 million and $15 million indicates that no‐one is really sure what impact this agreement will have on Australia. Specifically, Australian businesses investing in infrastructure in Vietnam should benefit from this tax exemption. It is on this ground that I support the bill.

However, this agreement has demonstrated big holes in the coalition's supposedly impervious treaty making process. Perhaps the Foreign Minister's new code of conduct is working well in the area of Foreign Affairs, but it is obviously not effective in the domain of the Treasury or the Australian Taxation Office. The Institute of Chartered Accountants and the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties have described substandard practices in both the timing and nature of consultation within industry.

Industry groups have called on the Australian Taxation Office to commit to a review procedure. A review of the ATO's method of consultation is, of course, of particular importance, given that the coalition government has indicated that it will negotiate as many double tax agreements as it can in the future, and I stress `as many as it can'. If double tax agreements are a necessary part of economic globalisation—and clearly they are—they need to be negotiated to maximise the benefits to Australia. That will necessitate a truly open and accountable process of consultation.

I understand that the ATO expects to present a proposal to the Treasurer later this week, seeking authority to consult more widely on international tax agreements. One option that the ATO is exploring is the publication of details of pending double tax agreements in the national printed media. That would certainly be a step in the right direction. However, it would not bring about a reform of the subjective manner in which the ATO arrives at the details of future tax treaties, if the present example is to be relied upon. Further, this proposal will not guarantee more time for discussion by experts and interested persons unless the ATO publishes, or makes available, details early on in the negotiation stage.

As I indicated earlier, Australia's dealings with Vietnam are limited relative to our trade with other nations. But what the International Tax Agreements Amendment Bill (No.1) 1997 serves to highlight is the critical need for a truly open and meaningful consultation process in this country. It is equally obvious that such a process is not operational at present.

It is the maintenance of checks and balances like those outlined by the Institute of Chartered Accountants that contributes towards a workable and sustainable democracy in Australia. Those proposals deserve serious consideration by the government. I repeat that I support the measure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous, Andrew, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Although the bill before us, the International Tax Agreements Amendment Bill (No.1) 1997, is not controversial in the sense that it is not being opposed, it is an important bill. I must commend the member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) for his excellent presentation of the issues involved in this bill and some of the problems related to it.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true to say that in a sense this bill is symbolic because it is dealing with one area. But the ramifications of the bill are huge in the sense that we also have agreements similar to this with Malaysia, Singapore, Sri Lanka, China, Kiribati and Korea, and we are looking to other agreements.
In this context, it is very important that we get the nature of these agreements correct and also that we learn some things about how we can benefit Australia in this process.

Essentially this proposal is concerned with the notion of tax sparing, which has to do with allowing Australian companies to gain a tax concession on the basis that they have been given a tax concession by the government of Vietnam. The government of Vietnam, like many Asian countries, gives tax concessions for investment in various industries and also concessions when profits are made.

BREAK.PARA: In this situation it is important that you do not get a negation of that effect by the company then having to pay tax in Australia and being put in an awkward position. This bill is intended to extend this notion of tax sparing in relation to Vietnam so that we have a situation where companies can claim the same concession basically being transferred into Australia.

It is interesting that this phenomenon is occurring and I read out before the other countries with which we have these arrangements—they are all Asian countries. What is important here is that it is in Asia that we see this massive effort—not just in Asia but primarily in Asia, especially in Vietnam, Malaysia, Singapore and China—to give big concessions to industry for investment.

I note this point in the context of Tuesday's federal budget. What was interesting in the federal budget was the complete absence of any incentives at all for Australian industry. You could not get a bigger contrast when you think about it.

We are supposed to think of ourselves as part of the Asian region and associate ourselves with the Asian region. Virtually every country in Asia gives significant and major concessions for industry development, especially manufacturing industries, and we do not. We don't do anything. There is absolutely no reason why anybody should invest in Australia when facing the kinds of concessions given to companies to invest, especially in manufacturing and production, in other parts of the world but especially in the Asian region.

Vietnam has opened up its economy and more and more foreign investment is going into Vietnam. I read recently that Vietnam is trying to copy what has been going on in China under the policies of Deng Xiaoping. I have just come back from a visit with a parliamentary delegation to China. You would not believe the development and the production that is going on there. It is very hard to believe.

This kind of development is also starting to happen in Vietnam. In China, they build whole cities like Shenzhen—with 3½ million people in 15 years—and huge skyscrapers, railway systems, roads, bridges, five‐star hotels and factories, one after the other. There is production, manufacturing and development.

Compared to all that dynamism, the Australian economy is a disgrace. Yet we are saying, `Let's try and get Australians involved in this process.' That is why I support this bill to get Australians involved in Vietnam and, by extension, in the other countries where we have double taxation arrangements.

But we have learnt nothing ourselves from all of the developments in the Asian region. We do not give these sorts of concessions; we do not even think about it. We are obsessed with only one thing and that is whether or not there is a surplus in the budget. We have no idea about spending a dollar so as to make two or three in the future, especially in infrastructure development.

It is very interesting that investments in infrastructure in Vietnam will be covered in these proposals, yet we ask ourselves, `What is happening with investment in infrastructure in Australia?' We have an infrastructure investment situation, but it is measly compared to what is required for this country.

When we think about budgeting, the analogy is often used about the household. The Treasurer (Mr Costello) said you cannot spend what you do not have. If you took that idea totally literally, nobody would ever buy a house on a mortgage because they certainly do not have the money. They have to borrow the money.

Borrowing for investment in growth, infrastructure and development of industry is an investment in the future. Such borrowing is going to come back in a positive way, just as when you invest in a house and you go to the bank and you borrow money, it comes back positively. That simple fundamental economic lesson seems to be one which is totally missed here because this government is totally obsessed with an ideology that is out of date; it has been rejected around the world. What are even conservative governments around the world doing? Most conservative governments are actually borrowing. They are investing, they are growing their economies, they are pushing them along—with the exception of the Australian government.

In relation to Vietnam and the other double taxation arrangements, as the member for Curtin mentioned, even this particular proposal is not sufficiently wide and open. A number of possibilities have been closed because this agreement was achieved without sufficient consultation with interested parties.

That shows the total ignorance our public servants have about what is happening in Asia. Basically, they are hopeless. The advice they have given to the government about what is happening in Asia—how the various countries of Asia are developing their economies, how they want Australian investment and Australian dual projects, how they want Australia to get into China, Vietnam and all those other countries—shows that our bureaucrats, our public servants, do not have a clue.

Let me give an example. What would happen to a businessman in Vietnam or China who applied for a visitors visa to come to Australia to have a look around and see what business he could do? He would probably be rejected. A number of businessmen in China and Vietnam and so on have been put off by the fact that they cannot come here because they cannot get a visa for a month or two to have a look around. They are given a grilling. This is our idea of how to do business with Asia.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not getting any better!

—The member for Curtin has pointed out the holes in this international tax agreement and the total failure to consult with Australians who have an interest in the matter. This is one example of what is going on. The reality is that unless we improve our approach, our knowledge, our understanding of what is going on in Asia, that unless we actually decide that we are going to get together with the communities in Asia in terms of dynamic economic development, then we are going to be left behind.

BREAK.PARA: Do not think that there are not alternatives to Australia for these people. There are alternatives. Other countries are already looking at taking a section of our trade, even primary commodities. If you think the business we already have is guaranteed, you should see the competition occurring amongst companies from all over the world that are trying to get into Vietnam, China and other Asian countries.

Australia was not admitted into the discussions between the European Community and the various countries of ASEAN. We were not admitted into the discussions between China and the European nations. The danger is that these arrangements will occur amongst Europe, the United States and the Asian nations and we will be left in some kind of backwater.

When we make agreements of this kind, we should have people go there, look at what is required, and do whatever we can to promote business, interconnections, trade and investment between Vietnam and Australia and, indeed, between China and Australia, as well as Malaysia, Singapore and the other countries of Asia. If we do not do that, we will be in a very serious situation.

This general arrangement of international tax agreements was initiated by the Labor government. It was, as I mentioned, one of several such agreements which the Labor government initiated. The previous Prime Minister had a commitment to improving links with Asia. He understood the importance of links, especially economic links, with Asia so that we could become part of the action in that dynamic region of the world.

Naturally, the Australian Labor Party was involved in developing these agreements and it supports the general thrust of the legislation although, I must say, I agree with the qualifications and the problems outlined by the member for Curtin. The legislation could have been more extensive. It could have allowed for greater investment and, most importantly, it could have been based on consultation between the people affected, in both Vietnam and the Australian companies and individuals interested in doing business with Vietnam.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was never the Labor way.
—What an idiotic comment from the minister. You have not heard a thing I have said, have you? You are such a fool.
—Order! The honourable member should not reflect on the member.
—I am not interested in his interjections, I can tell you that!
—Perhaps you could withdraw the comment `fool'.
—I withdraw the comment `fool', but I have been making a very serious—
—Thank you. If that is unequivocal, the honourable member may proceed.

—Yes. I have been making a very serious speech about the need for Australia to get involved in the economy of the Asian region. I have been comparing the Australian economy and the Asian economies. We are told that a growth of 3.75 per cent is a wonderful achievement when, in fact, the average growth of the Asian economies is about eight per cent—and some are reaching 10 per cent, 11 per cent or 12 per cent. Some regions of China are reaching 15 per cent growth levels, and yet we think that three to 3.5 per cent is going to be sufficient to achieve something in this country. We need a faster rate of growth and greater involvement and participation in the dynamism of the region.

BREAK.PARA: To conclude, we support this international agreement, although we feel that it could have been stronger. We also support increasing the number of such agreements and extending them to other countries in the region so that we can have closer liaison with those countries. However, we also make the point that we could learn from some of the initiatives being taken in the Asian region and from some of the major projects to bring industries and investments into those regions. We could learn from those exercises and we could do a hell of a lot better in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this morning to sum up on behalf of the government. I led a delegation of Vietnam veterans to Vietnam last year. During that visit, I saw first‐hand the enormous opportunity that presents itself in Vietnam, not only from the tourism point of view but also through the business opportunities for Australian businesses in Vietnam.

BREAK.PARA: There is no doubt that the International Tax Agreements Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1997 is a very important bill. It will give the force of law in Australia to the exchange of notes that took place on 22 November 1996 amending the Australia‐Vietnam double taxation agreement. The exchange of notes was announced by our Treasurer (Mr Costello) on 22 November 1996. The notes implement, effectively, the tax sparing provisions of the double tax agreement.

A benchmark rate of 20 per cent has been set for the Vietnamese tax otherwise payable. If the prevailing Vietnamese tax rate drops below 20 per cent that lower rate will become the benchmark. When the notes were negotiated, a variety of nominal tax rates were applicable to foreign investors in Vietnam, ranging from 25 per cent down to 10 per cent. Under the notes, the tax sparing is for the 10 years commencing from the date of effect of the Vietnamese double taxation arrangement, which is 1 July 1993.

The government firmly believes that this exchange of notes will contribute positively to the strengthening of trade and investment and to a wider relationship between Australia and Vietnam. That is particularly important, given the importance of its geographic location in the Asian area, but also because of the need to continue to strengthen our relationship with Vietnam.

Under the new arrangements introduced by this government to promote greater community awareness and discussion of treaty obligations, these notes and a national interest analysis were tabled in the House on 11 February 1997. The notes have already been reviewed by the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties.

This is the first tax treaty to be reviewed by the committee. It held two hearings on this treaty and took submissions from the Australian Taxation Office, the Institute of Chartered Accountants and the Australian Society for Certified Practising Accountants. It was during that process that a number of important issues concerning these notes were clarified. The committee reported on this treaty in March of this year.

The tabling of the committee hearings has permitted significant public debate and clarification of these notes already. The committee recommended that the exclusion of accounting and auditing services from the tax sparing would be kept under review and if Vietnamese legislation is amended, negotiations commenced to provide tax sparing. Importantly, the committee did not recommend changes to the notes and supported the early ratification.

It is important that we consider the fact that this is the very first bill that has been considered under the new arrangements that this government put in place in relation to international treaties. Under the previous administration you would not have had this process of consultation. Therefore, it is an important step forward and a very positive one. I think that coming out of it, it is important to make sure that we do proceed constructively in relation to the way that we deal with foreign treaties.

The member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) raised the issue of consultation. Can I say that the government will be positively looking at improving consultation as part of the treaty process. The government will be responding also to the recommendations of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties. Not only is this bill important from the point of view of international treaties, it is also important from the point of view of our relationships with other countries, and in this case Vietnam.
In conclusion, I want to thank those members from both sides of the House who have contributed to this debate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 March, on motion by Mr Williams:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melham, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose to speak only briefly in relation to this bill. The Crimes Amendment (Forensic Procedures) Bill 1997 represents the fulfilment of yet another commitment made by the previous Labor government. In the Justice Statement launched in May 1995, the previous Labor government committed itself to the introduction of:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a forensic procedures bill to allow police to apply for court orders to take samples from suspected criminals for identification.
As the Justice Statement went on to state:

The use of forensic samples is a very important tool in crime investigation. The compulsory taking of samples is necessary for effective law enforcement. The lack of such powers might advantage criminals. The Commonwealth legislation will build in substantial civil liberty safeguards.

Later in 1995, the Crimes Amendment (Forensic Procedures) Bill 1995 was introduced and passed through the House. That bill was based on the Model Forensic Procedures Bill developed by the Model Criminal Code Officers' Committee of the Standing Committee of Attorneys‐General. In turn, the model bill drew on the recommendations of the Report on Body Samples and Examinations published by the Victorian Consultative Committee on Police Powers of Investigation.

The 1995 bill found its way to the Senate and, following consideration by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee which reported in October 1995, the bill lapsed when the parliament was prorogued for the 1996 federal election.

The bill currently before the House relies heavily on the 1995 bill, although amendments have been made adopting most of the 20 unanimous recommendations of the Senate committee. Only three of those recommendations have not been adopted in full. Recommendations 1 and 3 sought to limit the power to take body samples and conduct examinations, particularly of breast swabs in the case of recommendation 3, to circumstances in which the offence was punishable by imprisonment for five years or more.

The government has applied this recommendation, save that it has reduced the scope of the exception to apply it to indictable offences only. It also appears, on the basis of further consideration, that the Senate committee, in agreeing to recommendation 3, failed to fully appreciate the nature of the procedures contemplated by the relevant provisions. Accordingly, the opposition believes that these amendments are appropriate.

Recommendation 2 prevented the taking of dental impressions. This recommendation was based on the state of forensic dontology as it was in 1995. I am advised that technical developments made since that time mean that low‐invasive techniques for the taking of dental impressions are now available.

BREAK.PARA: It follows that this bill remains, in essence, and largely in substance, Labor's 1995 bill. I note that this bill is also designed to serve as a model for state and territory forensic procedures bills. I hope that the various jurisdictions will give strong consideration to bringing their laws into line with those to be adopted in this bill. The consistency of Australian criminal law has long been overdue. As it is implemented, it will greatly enhance citizens' knowledge of and consistent treatment by the law. It will also enable our law enforcement authorities to spend less time worrying about which law they need to apply and more time catching and prosecuting criminals.

The benefits of the bill, both in its longer term use as a model for the states and territories and in its immediate application to provide consistency of forensic procedures for the prosecution of Commonwealth offences, are obvious. What concerns me on a personal level is that I had some reservations in the previous parliament on aspects of this bill. I voiced those reservations within the caucus committee of the Australian Labor Party. A number of those reservations are still relevant.

We have to be very careful as a parliament not to bring in legislation just to the lowest common denominator. If we are going to be invading people's liberties, then there has to be some protections. Whilst the opposition will be supporting this bill, I put on notice to the government that there are a number of submissions that I anticipate are still coming to the opposition as to how the bill could be improved.

I put the government on notice that, between the passage of this bill in the House of Representatives and its final consideration in the Senate, the opposition is going to be consulting with a number of community groups and individuals who are working at the coalface to ensure that this bill has adequate protections and to see whether it can be further improved.

We are not going to do that in a destructive manner. We hope to do it in a constructive fashion, because there have been some improvements in terms of forensic dontology and other aspects of forensic behaviour in that time. We also need to look at these things afresh. Some time has elapsed. We want to get the federal model right so that the states can pick it up, but we want to have the right balance. We want to be very careful that we do not put in some protections because they are too hard or because some states might not like them. I put that reservation on the table.

I have not been able to give specifics because we have not had further submissions, but I have been personally contacted by people in this area who lobbied me last time. I think it is a matter that I should put on the record, that on the previous bill I was not totally happy with it. We hope to discuss these matters with the government in a constructive fashion. The Labor Party does not want to just take an oppositionist role. These things have important ramifications when they affect the powers of police. I am not one who subscribes to the view that what we do is legislate to the lowest common denominator and then you have a situation where some police could abuse these powers. And that is the situation—there has been a number of royal commissions conducted around this country that show that police have abused powers that have been given to them.

By and large, the opposition is supporting this bill. It is an improvement on the bill that we introduced in the last parliament because the government has picked up some of the recommendations of the Senate committee. We would just ask that the government look again at some of the reservations that were in the Senate committee's report that did not form recommendations. There were some reservations of committee members and we would ask the government to have a look at whether, with the passage of time, some of those reservations might now be further considered to be put into this bill. The opposition commends the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Tony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am always very concerned about amendments to legislation which give police greater powers. I am always concerned that those sorts of amendments have to be carefully looked at. Having said that, I wish I had more time to carefully look at these amendments to the Crimes Amendments (Forensic Procedures) Bill. We must always remember what was said nearly 150 years ago by Vice‐Chancellor Knight‐Bruce, I think it was, in a case that I cannot remember the name of. In talking about the striving to get people convicted if they were guilty, he included a cautionary note in relation to the question of truth. He said, `It may be pursued too keenly. It may be loved unwisely. It may cost too much.' It is a principle that I think has to always be borne in mind in considering these sorts of matters.

SPEECH.PARA: It is always a matter of getting the balance right between the community's interest in ensuring that people who commit serious criminal offences are convicted and punished, and the interest of the individual who may be caught up in that process and who has been dealt with harshly in being so caught up. There have been a number of very prominent examples of that this century where individuals have been caught up. As I think I have said before in the House, once the criminal process begins it is not very nice to be on the other end of it. It is a very all‐embracing process and people who get swept up into it really find it very difficult to get out until those magic words are pronounced by the jury.

I have seen a number of cases where judges have virtually told juries to acquit because of the paucity of evidence and the way the investigative procedure has been conducted. With that in mind I also say that, on the other side of the coin, it is important for police to be armed in a modern age with all the powers that lead to the undertaking of forensic procedures so that they can carry out investigations in a thorough and proper way. The investigative arm conducted by the police is not frozen in time, and ought not to be frozen in time.

There are constant changes and developments in science and technology that must be kept pace with. In that regard I think it is also important, in the overall context of the community's interest in ensuring that guilty people do get found guilty and do get punished, to say that the end result must also be considered. I have, for example, great difficulty—I mention this since the Attorney‐General is here—with the fact that appeal courts can enter verdicts of acquittal where scientific evidence is being questioned.

A very notorious case in relation to that is the case of the Queen and Raymond Carroll. Carroll was charged with the murder of Deidre Kennedy. It was a shocking crime that occurred in 1973 in Ipswich where a 17‐month‐old child was murdered. Carroll was charged quite a number of years after—I think almost 10 years after—with the offence. He was found guilty by a jury but the court of criminal appeal quashed the conviction and entered a verdict of acquittal. In that case, the question of a bite mark on the child's thigh was concerned and the admissibility or reliability of various evidence about that particular matter came into close focus. With the advances in technology that case may well be able to be re‐opened but for the fact that the court of criminal appeal has pronounced on it.

I am not passing judgment on the Carroll case. What I am saying is that one must look at the overall need to ensure that guilty people are brought to justice and I question the powers that are given to appeal courts to enter verdicts of acquittal where scientific evidence is raised in sharp focus.

PARA.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—
Sitting suspended from 11.03 a.m. to 11.16 a.m.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr TONY SMITH —I am very concerned about the powers of the courts of appeal to enter verdicts of acquittal. I throw that into the melting pot merely to emphasis the fact that in a legislative package like this, we have to think of all of the ends that are sought to be achieved. It is no good having these sorts of procedures which are good, in general, if we do not also look at the powers of the courts of appeal. Generally speaking, I do not believe that a court of appeal ought to have the power to enter a verdict of acquittal, but there are always exceptions.

Very briefly, in relation to the bill, they are model provisions drawing on the 1989 Coldrey report. It is basically the creation of a code for taking bodily samples for examination. It balances the interest of the public and the rights of the suspect, and there is a great emphasis in the particular legislation on the rights of the suspect. Non‐consensual examination can occur within strict guidelines. It does end the present reliance upon varying state jurisdictions for their particular legislation. For example, in Queensland it is section 259 of the criminal code. In passing, I would like to have, as a defence lawyer, this particular set of provisions in Queensland instead of section 259, which is a fairly rigid section in terms of the powers that are given to take samples. I do not need to go into it, but the rights of suspects in relation to section 259 of the code are very much circumscribed. But, of course, there is always the supervisory jurisdiction of the court at trial and the exercise of discretionary principles that might arise under Bunning v Cross, and other cases.

I have mentioned before the fact that forensic science is not frozen; it is constantly evolving, and this has to be borne in mind. I have just a couple of concerns about the bill itself—I emphasis again, I have not read it all, unfortunately. I find a couple of inconsistencies in the bill and I think that these should be addressed. Generally, may I say at the outset, there is an awful tendency on the part of legislators, and even at courts of trial, for courts to patronise people of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander descent. At times, it can become nauseating at the bar table to hear prosecutors asking questions of Aboriginal people in a manner which I do not think is intentional, but gives the impression that they almost believe that the Aboriginal person does not have a brain at all.

I mention that in order to point out something that perhaps should be addressed in the legislation. Clause 23WX, subclauses (1) to (4), and also clause 23XR—by way of looking at the trend in the legislation—cover procedure, of course. Clause 23WX in part reads:
(2) A suspect who is:
(a) a child; or
(b) an incapable person;
must be represented by an interview friend and may also be represented by a legal practitioner.

(3) If the applicant believes on reasonable grounds that the suspect is an Aboriginal person or a Torres Strait Islander not covered by subsection (2), the suspect must be represented by an interview friend—
Please note the mandatory provisions—
and may also be represented by a legal practitioner.

(4) Subsection (3) does not apply if the applicant believes on reasonable grounds that, having regard to the suspect's level of education and understanding, the suspect is not at a disadvantage in relation to the hearing by comparison with members of the Australian community generally.

I have no problem with that provision. But you cannot say that, because a person is an Aboriginal, they are somehow different in terms of knowledge and understanding. So there ought to be a discretion for the applicant to make that assessment: it is quite common in other legislation. Similarly, there is that trend in clause 23XR.

But the time limits in the bill, in relation to people under some disability, are such that the examination for forensic procedures must be carried out within two hours, for a child or an incapable person not in custody. In relation to Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander persons, there is also a two hours mandatory provision. But, for a suspect not covered by either (1) or (2)—that is, not a child, an incapable person, an Aboriginal person or Torres Strait Islander person—the limit is four hours. I see that as inconsistent with the other clauses of the act. Really, there should be a discretion there—to follow the clauses that I have referred to—to permit a longer period if the applicant, the investigating police officer or some person involved in the investigation believes on reasonable grounds that, having regard to the suspect's level of education and understanding, the suspect is not at a disadvantage.

It seems to me to follow; otherwise, you are drawing a distinction between one section of the community and another, and there are plenty of people of European descent who are at great disadvantage in the community, and plenty of people of ethnic and other origins who also are at great disadvantage, and they are not covered. Looking at the rest of the act, I believe there should be a provision that allows a degree of liberality, if you like, so that we are not focusing on one section of the community and patronising it by saying that, somehow or other, that section of the community requires a two‐hour limit because we accept that that section of the community is simply not generally capable of having the same level of understanding and judgment that another section of the community has.

I can tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, from many cases I have done in your neck of the woods up in the South Burnett, there are many people of Aboriginal descent who, in terms of their level of understanding and knowledge, would leave for dead some people of European descent whom I have acted for. On the other side of the coin, there are people of Aboriginal descent who do need great assistance in relation to interview procedures and procedures of this particular nature. It is a matter that really ought to be looked at, to give some sort of consistency to the overall thing. I put that point respectfully, Mr Attorney, and I am sorry for the notice. I did speak to one of the officers only this morning about this. It is something that I think should be looked at, overall.

Another thing occurred to me: what about the position of transsexuals? I can imagine the case arising where a transsexual person is going to have to be examined. Where do we go, in terms of the act, with that person? That is going to happen. It is not so unusual to find oneself in that situation today, and yet that is really not covered in the bill. After all, we are trying to construct a piece of legislation which will lead to a more effective administration of the criminal justice system.

I have looked generally at other sections. As I say, it is a much more comprehensive piece of legislation, which I generally support—subject to those qualifications and subject to the fact that I have not considered the entirety of the bill. But, generally speaking, I support it as an instrument that balances fairly the needs of the community against the individual rights of the suspect who is being interviewed. Subject to those particular matters and the important matter of ensuring that the whole package in the criminal justice system is always looked at when one is introducing measures of this nature, I think, on the whole, it is a valuable piece of legislation in the Commonwealth Crimes Act and one that will, in my view, achieve a good deal of good by ensuring the administration of the criminal justice system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sercombe, Bob,MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) commenced his second reading speech by saying that the Crimes Amendment (Forensic Procedures) Bill is long overdue. It does, as previous speakers have indicated, arise from legislation that lapsed when the parliament was prorogued before the last election. As the member for Banks (Mr Melham) indicated, the opposition supports the legislation. On the basis of the bill including some of the proposals that have come out of the Senate committee process, it believes the legislation is in some respects a modest improvement on earlier legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation represents a very important step towards a higher level of commonality between the various criminal justice jurisdictions in Australia. In this area of the law, as the member for Dickson (Mr Tony Smith) indicated, there is not yet adequate commonality. Certainly, this legislation contributes to that and builds on the pioneering work that was done in Victoria and makes it better.

There are a whole range of areas in the administration of the Attorney‐General where evolving commonality is clearly desirable. Perhaps one of the closest examples to the processes involved in this legislation is the national automated fingerprint identification system—and that involves a very important collaborative effort between different jurisdictions.

I mention also the evolution of the role of the national exchange of police information process, the operations of the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence and the establishment and work of the National Institute for Forensic Science. There is a range of evolving areas where, as a national parliament and on a bipartisan basis, we ought to be doing everything possible to ensure that this greater degree of commonality between Australian jurisdictions continues to evolve. Obviously, the gun laws, in the context of the discussions here last year, are another important example of that on‐going evolution of commonality. This legislation, hopefully, will take that process forward in the very important area of forensic procedures.

The bill also seeks to strike the fundamentally important balance between ensuring the rights of the accused to fairness in the investigation and prosecution processes and ensuring that our law enforcement agencies have the advantage of the most up‐to‐date technical capacities in relation to investigation and prosecution.

I would imagine that the principal application of this legislation will be in the area of biological samples. In the forensic science area there is a range of other technologies that may relevant, including the analysis of textiles, for example, and the analysis of glass or metal specimens taken from crime scenes and the like. But I think it is in the biological specimens area that this will be the most relevant, and that is clearly a rapidly advancing area of technology and one which is very important for the reasons I have suggested. It is certainly a technology that has a very powerful capacity to implicate suspects. It also has, probably even more importantly, a very important power to exculpate or remove a suspect from consideration in relation to a particular offence.

We should not get too carried away by the importance of this—and I will get onto the point of not getting too carried away by the aura of science in a moment. In very serious offences such as murder, the scientific evidence may only be peripheral. In a large number of murder cases there would not be much doubt about the identity of the person who carried out the killing. The question before the court is usually one of intent rather than identity.

In relation to matters such as rape, often the courts are not dealing so much with identity or with the act of intercourse that may have occurred, but with the question of consent. The question of consent is often before the court in those matters. One should not be unduly carried away and think that this particular technology is going to solve all the problems, but it is clearly going to be important.

It needs to be understood that the aura of science should not dominate process. Not too long ago, in the United States in particular, serious questions were asked in the courts about DNA sampling. For example, in the early 1990s, arising primarily from a case called the Castro case, the US National Academy of Sciences said that DNA technology was sufficiently questionable for it to call for its non‐admissibility in relation to court matters.

Earlier in this decade, the Tran case in New South Wales was often talked about as one which raised serious questions about the quality of the DNA evidence being presented in our courts. I am advised by forensic scientists—and I make no pretence of understanding the particular technologies in a scientific sense—that PCR technology is now commonly used in most Australian jurisdictions, though I think there is some doubt about what Tasmania uses. As I understand it, many of the problems related to the adequacy of the scientific techniques and the scientific methodologies of earlier technologies have now been overcome.

I add the cautionary note that forensic science is not without its faults and problems. The most notorious case in recent times in Australia was the Chamberlain case, which led to the 1987 Morling Royal Commission of Inquiry into the Chamberlain Convictions. It was found that the scientific evidence in that particular case was seriously flawed. According to Morling, a number of tests were done without the results being verified. It found that there was a failure to use adequate controls, particularly in testing blood samples from the Chamberlain car.

The commission also found that testing was done on articles from which a clear result could not be expected and that there was a failure to use a control or scientific methodology in such circumstances. The commission found a failure to take adequate account of the effects of heat in a car with the effluxion of time when interpreting test results.

Things have moved on considerably since that time but, nonetheless, as well as the findings of the Morling royal commission in relation to scientific evidence, there has been a range of other cases, such as the Stuart matter in South Australia and the Shannon royal commission, which found reasonable doubt as to the validity of scientific evidence used in the conviction of Edward Charles Splat. The list goes on.

There has been a tendency unfortunately, I would submit, for police, courts and juries to give an aura to scientific evidence. In many cases that aura is undesirable. It has led to a situation where, as a community, we need to make sure that there are rigorous controls in relation to the evolution of that science at all times and that an adequate balance is achieved.

This legislation has considerable merit in that respect but it is a matter that needs to be continuously and rigorously looked at if injustices are to be minimised in the future. It is very important in that process that the commonality of approach between jurisdictions in Australia be rigorously pursued. If there are major problems in scientific evidence in one jurisdiction, that will discredit similar evidence in other jurisdictions. It will create circumstances where not only do innocent people run the risk of being convicted—as was the case in the Chamberlain matter—but where guilty people are not convicted because the evidence is tainted. This was the case earlier this decade, in my understanding, in the United States, where, as a result of the Castro case and the position argued by the Academy of Sciences in the US, there was very serious doubt. Guilty individuals who should have been convicted were not convicted because that evidence was not presented.

There are also questions of costs involved in this process. Once again, we do not want to get carried away, but it can be a very expensive technology. I understand that the Victorian Institute for Forensic Medicine charges something like a couple of hundred dollars to carry out elemental DNA testing. In some circumstances, that can rise significantly higher, so there are limitations on the utility of some of this stuff.

The bill also provides for the establishment of a database where blood samples are taken from individuals convicted of serious offences. That is going to be an extremely important tool to investigations provided it is properly managed and properly utilised in the same way as the national automated fingerprint identification system. But it is a more complex matter and a more difficult matter than fingerprinting.

There was a story in the Australian on 3 April which was headed, `Criminals in line for DNA database'. Perhaps the Attorney‐General, in winding up this particular debate, might be able to update us as to where the evolution of that particular proposal is. It is clearly a very important one, but it is one that, in the context of forensic evidence generally, because of its importance both in implicating and exculpating suspects, needs to be extraordinarily carefully managed if it is to retain credibility.

I am sure that the database is not going to be particularly useful in prosecutions. I would have thought that if it was put before a court or a jury that a significant basis for prosecution was that the person had been checked off on the database and a match had been found, that would be clearly indicating to the jury that the person had prior convictions. By definition, a person is not going to be on the database if they have not had a prior conviction. A person is entitled to be tried without the jury having knowledge of prior convictions. How the database will be used in the process of prosecution or what the utility of it is in that respect is very much a matter for discussion. I would welcome any comments from the Attorney‐General on that. It is quite clear to me at least. I hope that the relevance of the database is going to be for investigation and not for prosecution.

Overall, the opposition does support the bill, as I indicated at the outset. In fact, the member for Banks indicated that there are some modest improvements in the legislation as a result of the government picking up some of the Senate committee's points. We wish it rapid progress. But I have a feeling that the legislation is going to be back before the parliament in the not too distant future, given the fairly dynamic nature of this area and the evolution of forensic science for some further update, and that seems eminently sensible and appropriate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly, Jackie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Crimes Amendment (Forensic Procedures) Bill 1997 is an example of parliament trying to keep pace with rapidly changing technology. It can be seen in a number of other areas that are readily used today such as the Internet, where our children find it very second‐nature. I think the older generation has some difficulty coming to grips with it. The problems are then with parliament. With it being prorogued, our major democratic system finally comes round to catching up, as it were, to technology.

SPEECH.PARA: The technology here is not very high flying. There are things as basic as fingerprinting. We have gone so far with DNA identification now that we can actually isolate genes which are causing a particular disease and treat embryos before they are born. There is the ability to clone animals, and there is some doubt whether the technology exists yet to clone human beings. Technology is presenting us with so many moral questions well ahead of our human and moral development to be able to answer any of those questions.

While you have crime in the community, people's perception of crime escalates. They become very apprehensive about crime, demanding solutions to the problem that is affecting them in their environment. This is true especially of females in that the ordinary use of the community is severely curtailed by apprehension about their movements after dark, thinking, `Am I alone?' or `Is the taxi safe?' Every female suffers some curtailment of her ordinary right to the night by that fear of crime, especially rape and sexual abuse. That severely curtails females' rights to go about their business in society and it changes their behavioural patterns quite considerably.

Women are demanding some action on that. They can see where technology is going. They can see the extraordinary science that is available and they also see a number of alleged criminals beating the rap. Often in a lot of sexual abuse and rape crisis counselling the female is put on trial at the trial rather than the suspect. This sort of technology just facilitates the police roles and meets the public demand for not only apprehension but conviction. This sends a clear message to the community that crime does not pay—`You will be apprehended and the chances of you getting off are very narrow; we will have all sorts of technology to beat you.' Certainly in the future, the way that technology is going, that will be so.

Currently, the forensic procedures we are looking at are really quite basic and non‐intrusive. I refer to the external examination of the genitalia or anal area, the buttocks, or, in the case of the female, the breasts; the taking of a sample of blood; the taking of a sample of saliva or a sample by buccal swab; the taking of a sample of pubic hair; the taking of a sample by washing from the external genitalia or anal area of the buttocks or, in the case of the female, the breasts; the taking of a sample by vacuum suction; scraping or lifting by tape from the external genital or anal area, the buttocks or, in the case of a female, the breasts; and the taking of a dental impression. These are not really the intrusive types of examination that is available and will get exceptional results.

The dignity of the suspect is also protected in a number of areas in terms of who is able to take that sample. It generally has to be an appropriately qualified person, generally a medical practitioner, a nurse or a dentist. In some cases, such as taking a sample of hair, other than pubic hair, or the taking of handprints, fingerprints, toeprints or footprints, it can be a constable. So we are setting up safeguards to protect the suspect's dignity. Obviously the samples will be taken by individuals of the same sex and there is the option to have the whole procedure videotaped or recorded. Again, that is protecting the suspect. They can decline to have a video taken and, again, that protects their dignity.

There is also an important section, clause 23XU, which provides for the sharing of samples with the suspect. In other words, if any samples are collected, the suspect must be given an examinable amount so that he can carry out his own testing procedures, using his own expert. If there is not a sufficient amount taken to provide that, then he is entitled to be present when the appropriately qualified person tests that sample. That is an important preservation of the suspect's rights.

As the member for Maribyrnong (Mr Sercombe) said, there is a lot of scepticism about technology today. I think the Lindy Chamberlain case was the classic case. There is scepticism about technology: yes it is high tech, yes it is very accurate, but how many people are experts? Whenever you introduce technology into a bureaucracy, and you give it to people who signed up as policemen 20 years ago to organise, there is some standardising that has to occur. There has to be some training and there has to be some expertise developed in the area to satisfy people's wariness of new technology. The classic example is radar traps. We are still having ongoing disputes about the use of radar in order to convict speeding motorists. That technology is still being challenged in the courts and the operators are being found to be wanting in some cases.

When you introduce technology it has to be probably not as current as what is available, but it has to be sufficient that those currently in the field can get up to speed with it, and use it appropriately and accurately. It is the accuracy that is available to us with modern technology that is being sought and demanded by the public. They are demanding not just an apprehension or far flung accusations; they are demanding a conviction. This technology is there and, in the future, I think criminals will be very wary about their prospects of getting away with anything as more and more technology is incorporated into police procedure.

Currently, we have seen a classic move in the drugs scene where people have gone from secreting a drug in their luggage and passing it through Customs in various forms, to having it on the person, strapped around the body, and now to it actually being in bodily cavities. As technology moves and as police procedures move towards apprehension, the criminals, who do read papers and are aware of the movements and the powers of police, continue to move to avoid them.

These procedures are just one step in the continual process of being able to apprehend and convict people who have committed crimes in our society. I think the member for Maribyrnong had some scepticism about the databases that can be created from these procedures. They are purely statistical and statistics are very important. He mentioned a few in relation to whether it was actually the intercourse in a rape case which was being disputed or whether it was the consent.

With statistics, police can analyse where their cases are falling down and where further funds need to be spent to repair the holes in the prosecution case. With the statistics which will be collected on that database of samples and of convicted people, we will start being able to profile things. There are safeguards such that personal information relating to that sample can be deleted. It really is a database just to give us more information on crime and to analyse crime, criminals and our actual conviction procedures.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is almost completely right, but it is only for this biological material.

—That is an important point too, because a lot of the material is time delayed. A lot of material has to be tested within a certain time, a lot of material has to be destroyed when it is tested. If that is so and that material is destroyed in the testing process, then the prosecution is unable to admit that in the case. It is only admissible by the suspect if the material is destroyed in the testing process, so any analysis out of that material cannot be used in evidence against them. That is safeguarding the suspect's right.

SPEECH.PARA: The whole movement today in criminal apprehension is always a balancing act between demands of society for the right to go about their business, and use public areas with immunity, and the individual's right to be treated with dignity, to be innocent until proven guilty and not to have to submit to a number of invasive or intrusive or degrading procedures to prove his innocence or otherwise. It is always a balancing act. This act has certainly got the balance fairly in favour of the suspects. You will still see a greater push by victims of violent crime wanting greater powers of investigation and greater certainty in conviction, and procedures where the witness does not have to go through the whole trial again with forensic evidence when a lot of circumstantial evidence is able to be produced which clearly puts the criminal at the scene of the crime. With an act of sexual intercourse or with drugs, it puts them fairly well in a limited narrow sphere where they are relying on defence such as consent or very legal technicalities to get out of it.

The important message is that the rope is closing. We are doing more. We are moving a fair way down the track to give the night back to females and to really frighten off the criminals with the certainty that they will be caught. We do have national legislation, which will gradually see adoption throughout all the states, where they cannot come to the ludicrous situation that occurred with one of my constituents. The sexual assault occurred in Tasmania, the offender went to Victoria, they moved to New South Wales, and nothing has happened because, out of the three jurisdictions, it all got too complex. Evidence collected in Tasmania would not be admissible in New South Wales.

Very complex jurisdictional issues are a great loophole for criminals to scoot through. It is certainly something that we have to make a move to legislate on and give to Australians in such a mobile and fast‐moving society. We are no longer the Federation of 1901 of a two‐day draycart drive to Melbourne. Within an hour, you are changing states, you are getting out of jurisdiction and you are getting away with murder. It is important that we send a very national message that the rope is closing, it will not be tolerated and we will keep moving in this direction. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I want to start by thanking members who have spoken today, the member for Banks (Mr Melham), the member for Dickson (Mr Tony Smith), the member for Maribyrnong (Mr Sercombe) and the member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly), for their valuable contributions. This bill does raise a number of difficult questions for us as legislators. As the member for Maribyrnong reminded the committee in the second reading speech, I indicated that it is a bill that is long overdue.

SPEECH.PARA: At present there is no general Commonwealth law dealing with medical or forensic examination of persons in lawful custody. The state and territory laws on which the Commonwealth currently relies are often unclear and subject to varying and limited safeguards. As the member for Lindsay has pointed out in her concluding remarks, the virtues of uniformity are plain.

This bill has been developed after a most exhaustive process of consultation. I believe that it achieves a right balance between the privacy of the individual and the needs of effective law enforcement. If that puts me at odds with the member for Lindsay who thinks that it favours the offender, then we will have to agree to differ.

It does provide a comprehensive scheme for obtaining forensic samples, setting out in clear detail the powers and obligations of police and an exhaustive range of safeguards to protect the rights of individuals, with particular provisions for Aboriginal persons, Torres Strait Islanders, children and incapable persons. Unless a suspect gives his or her informed consent after receiving all of the relevant information, including the right to refuse, no intimate procedure may be performed except by order of a magistrate. To make that order, the magistrate must be satisfied that there are reasonable grounds to believe that the person committed a relevant offence, that is, the same standard as for arrest. However, if a person is in lawful custody, non‐intimate procedures may be carried out by appropriately qualified persons, as ordered by a senior constable.

Further safeguards include: time limits for conducting procedures; the right to contact a lawyer and to communicate with him or her in private wherever possible; the right of certain suspects to interview friends; the right to an interpreter when necessary; tape recording of requests to consent and the conduct of procedures, and the provision of full information about the relevant procedure.

Most importantly, the bill includes a legislative barrier to the admissibility of evidence which is obtained from forensic procedures which are carried out in breach of the legislation. All procedures must be carried out by appropriately qualified persons. There is a right to have a medical practitioner of choice present during most procedures, and a medical practitioner of the same sex if practicable. There are limitations on the numbers of constables that may be present during the carrying out of a forensic procedure and restriction on the presence of opposite sex constables to cases of necessity. There are also comprehensive requirements for the destruction of forensic material after a conviction is secured or charges dropped.

The government is grateful for what might be described as the lack of opposition by the opposition to the bill, although the member for Banks did indicate that the opposition proposed to monitor the debate in order to see whether the bill could be improved during its passage through parliament. That is, of course, legitimate. It would help that if any deficiencies, or alleged deficiencies, are identified, they are made known to us so that the issue can be addressed and an appropriate answer can be given if there is one.

The member for Banks raised the issue of certain recommendations of the Senate Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs not being accepted by the government. Among the Senate committee recommendations which were not taken up are some I will mention.

Recommendation 1 limits the operation of the bill to offences with a maximum penalty of five years or more. This has not been adopted. The relevant offences tend to have maximum penalties of two to five years, being offences against the person in the main. The most useful application of the procedures would be excluded if it were limited to those with a penalty of five years or more.

Reference is made to dental impressions. I think the member for Banks acknowledged that there had been an advance in technology since the original bill was prepared. Evidence before the committee, I am advised, was in fact outdated and came from the mid‐1980s. The government has received up‐to‐date expert advice, which indicates that such evidence, using modern techniques, is both reliable and useful.

The third recommendation was that the examination of female breasts should only be in relation to alleged offences of over five years maximum penalty. Similar arguments apply to that as I offered in relation to the non‐adoption of the first recommendation. In certain crimes, especially violent or sexual crimes, evidence may be found on any part of the body, and the government saw no more reason to exclude the female breast area, subject to appropriate safeguards, than any other area of the body.

Recommendation 9 was to the effect that the suspect definition be confined to persons a constable believes, rather than suspects, on reasonable grounds to have committed a relevant offence. That has not been picked up. That would have had the effect of excluding many people from the protections of the bill. The police could still seek their consent for procedures, as they can for non‐suspects, but the protections in the bill would not apply. Several other recommendations, which were not fully accepted, were in fact accepted in part or in spirit or implemented in a somewhat different way. Greater detail on these matters can be found in the government's formal response to the committee's recommendations.

The member for Dickson expressed some concern about aspects of the bill relating to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, particularly the possibly patronising effect or appearance of provisions treating Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders as disadvantaged. He pointed out that this would be the case no matter how well educated or socially competent they may be. He gave an example in relation to the application of the lower two‐hour time limit for the procedures in relation to those people.

That provision and similar provisions in part 1C of the Crimes Act, relating to pre‐charge investigation periods, were inserted following full consultation with Aboriginal organisations and also result from recommendations of the Senate committee. The government was aware of and concerned about the possibly patronising connotations. But those, it appears, were outweighed by the benefits of the provision in the eyes of the affected groups consulted.

The member for Maribyrnong expressed some reservations about the reliability of DNA evidence and he raised some questions about databases.
